faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.subtitle: Everything you need to know about our assistive devices

q1.question: What is 3D printing and how does it work?
q1.answer: 3D printing is an additive manufacturing technology that creates physical objects layer by layer from a digital model. A 3D printer heats a plastic filament (usually PLA or PETG) and deposits it precisely to build the desired object. It's like a regular printer, but in three dimensions.

q2.question: Do I need to have a 3D printer at home?
q2.answer: Not necessarily. You can use the generated STL file at local 3D printing services, makerspaces, public libraries, technical schools, or even order printing online. Many cities have community spaces with 3D printers available.

q3.question: How much does it cost to print a device?
q3.answer: The cost varies depending on the device size and material used, but generally ranges from $1 to $6 in materials. If you use a printing service, there may be additional labor costs. Still, it's much more affordable than traditional custom devices, which can cost hundreds of dollars.

q4.question: What material should I use for printing?
q4.answer: We recommend PLA for most devices as it's safe, easy to print, and suitable for hand contact. PETG is a more durable alternative and heat-resistant. For kitchen utensils, make sure to use food-safe filaments and clean properly after use.

q5.question: How do I measure the hand correctly?
q5.answer: Check our "How to Measure" page for a detailed guide with illustrations. In summary, you'll need to measure hand length (from middle finger tip to wrist), palm width, and comfortable grip diameter using a ruler in centimeters.

q6.question: Do the devices work for all types of Parkinson's?
q6.answer: The devices can help at different stages of Parkinson's, especially with tremors and grip difficulties. However, each case is unique. We always recommend consulting a doctor or occupational therapist to assess whether the device is suitable for your specific needs.

q7.question: How do I clean and maintain the devices?
q7.answer: Wash with warm water and mild soap. Don't use very hot water, as it can deform the plastic. Dry completely before use. For kitchen utensils, hand washing is recommended instead of dishwasher.

q8.question: Can I adjust the device if it's not comfortable?
q8.answer: Yes! One of the great advantages of 3D printing is that you can generate new files with adjusted measurements as many times as needed, at no additional cost. Just return to the product page, enter new measurements, and generate a new STL file.

q9.question: How long does it take to print a device?
q9.answer: It depends on size and complexity, but generally between 2 to 6 hours. Smaller devices like pen grips can take 2-3 hours, while adapted utensils can take 4-6 hours. Printing is automatic, so you can leave the printer working overnight.

q10.question: Do the devices replace medical treatment?
q10.answer: No. These devices are auxiliary and can improve quality of life and autonomy, but they don't replace medication, physical therapy, or medical follow-up. Always consult health professionals about your treatment.

q11.question: Can I use the files commercially?
q11.answer: The generated files are for personal and non-commercial use. You can print for yourself or to help family and friends, but you should not sell the printed devices or STL files.

q12.question: What if I have problems with the file or printing?
q12.answer: Contact us through our contact form. While we can't provide technical support for specific printers, we can help with issues related to STL files or measurement adjustments.

howToMeasure.title: How to Measure Your Hand
howToMeasure.subtitle: Simple guide to get accurate measurements and customize your device

materials.paper: Paper and pen to note measurements

measurement1.title: Hand Length
measurement1.description: Measure from the tip of the middle finger to the first wrist line (where the palm begins).
measurement1.tip: Keep the hand relaxed and flat on a surface. The hand should not be clenched or fully stretched.

measurement2.title: Hand Width
measurement2.description: Measure the palm width at its widest part, usually at the base of the fingers, from the outer edge of the index finger to the outer edge of the little finger.
measurement2.tip: Don't force the fingers. Leave the hand in a natural and comfortable position.

measurement3.title: Hand Thickness
measurement3.description: Measure the hand thickness from the back of the hand to the palm at its thickest point (usually across the metacarpals). Use a ruler or caliper and keep the hand relaxed—do not squeeze.
measurement3.tip: Take the measurement with the hand in a natural position. If there is swelling, prefer the larger value for comfort.

considerations.title: Important Considerations
considerations.c1: All measurements should be in centimeters with one decimal place (e.g. 18.5 cm)
considerations.c2: Always measure the dominant hand (the hand that will be used to hold the device)
considerations.c3: If there is edema (swelling), consider the hand measurements in normal state
considerations.c4: When in doubt between two measurements, prefer the larger one to ensure comfort

about.title: About the Project
about.subtitle: Combining technology and empathy to create accessible solutions

mission.title: Our Mission
mission.description: To democratize access to personalized assistive technologies through 3D printing. We believe that every person with Parkinson's deserves devices adapted to their unique anatomy, enabling greater autonomy and quality of life in daily activities.

problem.title: The Problem
problem.p1: Parkinson's affects more than 10 million people worldwide. Tremors, muscle rigidity and motor difficulties turn simple activities like eating, writing and holding objects into real challenges.
problem.p2: Generic assistive devices rarely meet individual needs. Each person has different anatomy, and personalized solutions are often expensive and inaccessible.

solution.title: Our Solution
solution.p1: Through 3D printing and parametric design, we create personalized assistive devices affordably. Our platform transforms simple hand measurements into 3D models optimized for each patient.
solution.p2: Anyone with access to a 3D printer — at home, libraries, schools or makerspaces — can create personalized devices, eliminating cost and distribution barriers.

design.title: Human-Centered Design
design.intro: Our work is guided by principles of universal and user-centered design. Each device is:
design.ergonomicDesc: Adapted to individual anatomy and comfort
design.functionalDesc: Designed to reduce tremors and facilitate movements
design.respectfulDesc: Discreet and dignified design, not stigmatizing

important.title: Important
important.description: The devices on this platform are auxiliary and do not replace professional medical treatment. Always consult a doctor or occupational therapist about the best solutions for each specific case.

printers.title: 3D Printers
printers.subtitle: The transformative power of production decentralization
printers.hero: 3D printers are revolutionizing how we produce, distribute and access products. More than a technology, they represent a fundamental shift: from the centralized manufacturing model to a decentralized, democratic, and sustainable future.

industrial.title: From Industrial Revolution to Digital Revolution
industrial.p1: For centuries, mass production required giant factories, complex supply chains, and global distribution. Standardized products were manufactured by the millions, but personalization was impossible or prohibitively expensive.
industrial.p2: 3D printers reverse this paradigm: the factory comes to the user, not the other way around. Anyone with access to a printer can produce locally, on-demand, and personalized.

decentralization.title: Decentralization: Power in the Hands of Many
decentralization.intro: Production decentralization means communities, schools, libraries and even families can manufacture what they need, when they need it:
decentralization.eliminationDesc: No distributors, wholesalers, or importers — drastically reducing costs
decentralization.independenceDesc: Remote communities or developing countries can produce locally
decentralization.onDemandDesc: No inventory, no waste — only what's necessary is manufactured
decentralization.personalizationDesc: Each product can be unique, adapted to individual needs

impact.title: Social Impact and Democratization
impact.intro: 3D printers have transformative potential especially in areas like healthcare, education, and accessibility:
impact.healthcareDesc: Prosthetics, orthotics, assistive devices, and medical tools can be personalized and produced at a fraction of traditional costs, democratizing access to quality healthcare.
impact.educationDesc: Schools and universities can teach design, engineering, and manufacturing hands-on, empowering the next generation of inventors.
impact.sustainabilityDesc: Local production drastically reduces transportation emissions. Materials can be recycled or biodegradable, creating a circular economy.

speed.title: Speed of Transformation
speed.p1: What once took weeks of international shipping now takes hours of local printing. What cost thousands in tooling now costs pennies in plastic material. What required engineering teams can now be done by a single person with free software.
speed.p2: This speed of transformation is just beginning. New materials (metals, ceramics, biocompatible), faster printers, and smarter software will further expand possibilities.

makerspaces.title: Makerspaces and Collaboration
makerspaces.p1: You don't need to own a 3D printer to benefit from this revolution. Makerspaces, FabLabs, public libraries, and specialized cafés offer shared access to this technology.
makerspaces.p2: Even more important: online communities share designs for free. Millions of 3D models are available for download, adaptation, and immediate printing. Open knowledge + local manufacturing = decentralized power.

platform.title: Our Platform: Decentralization in Action
platform.intro: This project is a practical example of the power of decentralization. Instead of manufacturing assistive devices in a factory and shipping them to customers:
platform.step1: You measure your own hand at home
platform.step2: Our software generates a personalized 3D model instantly
platform.step3: You print locally — at home, library, or makerspace
platform.step4: The device is ready in hours, not weeks
platform.conclusion: This is the future of manufacturing: decentralized, personalized, accessible, and human.

cta.title: A New Era of Production
cta.description: 3D printers are not just tools — they are catalysts for social transformation. By decentralizing production, we democratize access, empower communities, and create a future where technology truly serves humanity.

distributed.title: Distributed Manufacturing
distributed.subtitle: The Transformative Power of Decentralization
distributed.p1: 3D printing represents a fundamental shift in how we produce, distribute, and access products. More than a technology, it enables a move from centralized manufacturing to a decentralized, democratic, and sustainable model of production.
distributed.p2: For centuries, mass production relied on large factories, complex supply chains, and global distribution. Products were standardized and personalization was either impossible or prohibitively expensive. Distributed digital fabrication reverses this logic: the factory comes to the user, not the other way around. Digital files travel globally, while objects are produced locally, on demand, and adapted to individual needs.
distributed.p3: Decentralized production places power in the hands of communities, schools, libraries, healthcare institutions, and families. By eliminating intermediaries, reducing transportation, and enabling on-demand manufacturing, this model lowers costs, minimizes waste, and allows each product to be uniquely customized.
distributed.p4: The impact of this shift is especially significant in healthcare, education, and accessibility. Assistive devices can be produced locally at a fraction of traditional costs, education becomes hands-on and experimental, and sustainability is reinforced through reduced emissions and local material use.

decentralization.title: Decentralization in Practice
decentralization.subtitle: Open Knowledge, Local Production
decentralization.p1: You don’t need to own a 3D printer to benefit from this transformation. Makerspaces, FabLabs, public libraries, schools, and community workshops provide shared access to fabrication technologies, while global online communities freely share design knowledge.
decentralization.p2: This project is a practical example of these principles in action. Instead of manufacturing assistive devices in centralized factories and shipping them worldwide, the platform enables a Sustainable Product–Service System (SPSS) based on open-source design and local production.
decentralization.p3: Users measure their hands, the platform generates a personalized 3D model, and devices are produced locally—in hours, not weeks. All files are free to download, modify, and adapt.
decentralization.p4: The designs provided on this platform are optimized for FDM 3D printers, the most common and affordable printing technology available today, ensuring broad compatibility with low-cost machines and shared fabrication spaces. This approach replaces mass production with personalization by default, strengthening local economies while making assistive technology more accessible, adaptable, and human.
